Situation1: They notice their parents appear more stressed and tired than usual.
Expectation2: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation2: A noise complaint has circulated on the floor, and a face-to-face meeting in the lobby calls for extra courtesy.
Story:
I noticed my parents seemed more worn out than ever lately—my mother’s eyes lingered on the floor, and my father’s voice was quieter at dinner. I knew they needed me to be present, to listen, to offer comfort. Tonight, I planned to sit with them, maybe make tea, and just be there. But as I was about to head to the kitchen, my phone buzzed with a message from the building group chat: a noise complaint had been made about our apartment. My heart sank. I remembered the laughter from last night’s movie, the clatter of dishes. 

Just then, I saw Mrs. Lee, our neighbor, waiting in the lobby. She smiled, but her eyes were searching. I knew I had to be extra polite, to smooth things over, to show I was a considerate neighbor. But my mind was split—my parents needed me upstairs, and Mrs. Lee expected a friendly, apologetic neighbor right now. I felt the pressure mounting, torn between the comfort my parents deserved and the courtesy my neighbor required. My feet felt rooted to the spot, my heart pounding as I tried to decide which door to walk through first.
